image.altText: group of lifeguards, most with faces blurred

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation tracks former Sunshine Coast teacher and coach Dean Carelse to a family holiday park in south-west England.

title.children: Queensland paedophile and former water polo coach employed as children's lifeguard in UK

image.altText: GPS tracker on an ankle with person wearing a black shoe.

props.synopsis: The immigration minister rejects suggestions the government lifted ankle monitoring devices from a number of detainees in order to scupper legal challenges to the laws launched in the High Court.

title.children: Detainees scrap High Court challenges after government removes ankle monitoring devices

image.altText: an aerial of a flooded road

props.synopsis: Residents in outback Queensland are preparing for further heavy rain, flash flooding, and dangerous winds as ex-Tropical Cyclone Kirrily intensifies in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

title.children: 'Nervous' outback towns brace for flash floods from ex-Tropical Cyclone Kirrily

image.altText: A composite image shows Georgie Purcell in two photos which appear identical except for changes to her clothing.

props.synopsis: A graphics expert says Nine News's explanation for how a digitally altered photo of Victorian Animal Rights Party MP Georgie Purcell was put to air is plausible — and raises important questions over the way the technology is used across society.

title.children: Is Nine's Photoshop explanation for an MP's altered image plausible? Here's what we found

image.altText: A woman leans on a fence on a rural property.

props.synopsis: Janet Ainscow lives next door to the stable of Tasmania's leading harness racing trainer. She's been speaking out about allegations of team driving at race meets, and the conditions horses are being kept in. It's taken years, but she now feels vindicated.

title.children: Horse trainer Ben Yole's neighbour blew the whistle on him. She finally feels 'vindicated'

image.altText: Ripped lease agreement with keys on table

props.synopsis: Renters asking to break their lease are required to compensate the landlord for financial losses, including paying rent until a new tenant is found, but critically low vacancy rates and high demand for housing mean that process is happening a lot faster than before the pandemic.

title.children: Rental crisis delivering a 'silver lining' for Queensland tenants who want to break their lease early

image.altText: An officer standing by a sign that advisers drivers of RBT and drug testing

props.synopsis: An expansion to Queensland's list of detectable drugs during random roadside intercepts identified 322 drug driving offences involving cocaine in its first six months between July and December last year.

title.children: Hundreds of drivers caught with cocaine in their system by new roadside testing regime

image.altText: A blurred person in the back of a police paddywagon in Queensland

props.synopsis: Taskforce Guardian has arrested hundreds of repeat offenders since it was created, but is it actually solving youth crime?

title.children: Millions have been spent on this youth crime taskforce. Is it working?

image.altText: Child stuck shopping centre

props.synopsis: Police say the three-year-old climbed into the machine through its prize dispenser.

title.children: Police break glass to rescue 3yo stuck in claw machine at Queensland shopping centre

image.altText: Two women embrace outside a burnt building.

props.synopsis: Many Israelis say that they will never forgive Palestinians for what Hamas did. It's this "never forgiving" that puts the two sides further apart than ever in this decades-old conflict, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Jump on a plane to Israel and you'll see one of the enduring ways life has changed since October 7

image.altText: Onlookers observe a UN sanctioned mining site in Hpakant area of Kachin state, northern Myanmar

props.synopsis: Justice For Myanmar reported that almost a dozen Australian and Australian-linked mining companies are still operating in the country and investing in its resources sector.

title.children: New sanctions against Myanmar junta don't include Australian-linked mining companies

image.altText: Man looks back at crowd of cameras watching him

props.synopsis: The Move Forward Party was attempting to change some of the world's strictest defamation laws and now faces the risk of dissolution and a ban on its leaders after losing the legal case.

title.children: Thailand's most popular political party faces dissolution after failed bid to change defamation laws

image.altText: Close-up of Daniel Keneally, disgraced police officer outside Downing Centre Local Court

props.synopsis: The disgraced police officer son of former senator Kristina Keneally has been handed a 15-month intensive correction order.

title.children: Son of former NSW premier sentenced for fabricating evidence that put innocent man in jail

image.altText: A young woman and a young man stand with arms oustretched in front of a small

props.synopsis: We wanted to own our own home without getting too far into debt, so we built a modest one-bedroom home on a block of land in regional Tasmania, with plans to extend it in the future.

title.children: How a young couple built the modest one-bedroom home they could afford

image.altText: Kurtley Beale outside court wearing a suit and tie

props.synopsis: During the call, former Wallabies star Kurtley Beale told the woman he is accused of sexually assaulting, he "misjudged the whole scenario" and apologised multiple times, the court heard.

title.children: 'Convince him he's guilty': Woman accusing Kurtley Beale of sexual assault made notes before phone call, court told

image.altText: A power pole with three wires, one of which has been cut.

props.synopsis: One business owner had his water pipes blow out because he was unable to monitor the pressure of his 140-kilometre-long system.

title.children: Copper thieves trigger three-week Telstra outage, pipeline blowout in NSW wine country

image.altText: achel Hunter speaking during an Estimates Hearing at Parliament House in Brisbane

props.synopsis: With more than 43,000 people waiting on Queensland's social housing register, a former top bureaucrat is tasked to review the state's response to homelessness with new funding for specialist support groups as a housing plan takes shape.

title.children: Former top public servant to lead Queensland homelessness review as part of housing plan

image.altText: Rainbow lorikeets in single beds in care.

props.synopsis: More than 200 birds with lorikeet paralysis syndrome have been taken in by wildlife carers around Grafton as researchers call on citizen scientists to help find the cause.

title.children: Rainbow lorikeets falling from the sky with mysterious syndrome in northern New South Wales

image.altText: A man and woman's hands cradle the woman's pregnant belly.

props.synopsis: The statistic has prompted Queensland Health Minister Shannon Fentiman to order an in-depth clinical review into the problem.

title.children: More babies die within 28 days of birth in Queensland than across most of Australia

image.altText: The back of a van, with a decal on it that reads Post Office

props.synopsis: When British post offices introduced a new accounting system more than two decades ago, money started going missing — what happened next has been described by some as the country's biggest ever miscarriage of justice.

title.children: 'They were like the mafia': When money went missing from post offices, everyone was looking in the wrong place

image.altText: A young man hugs his girlfriend whose face is blurred as they stand in front of a park

props.synopsis: Prosecutors tell a court Andre Rebelo was in financial strife and murdered his mother to gain access to her money.

title.children: Perth man killed his mother for her life insurance money, prosecutors will allege

image.altText: Elmo sitting in a cardboard box, with a slightly bewildered looking expression on his face

props.synopsis: The Sesame Street character says it's important for people to check in on their mates after being inundated with messages of despair.

title.children: Elmo asked social media users how they were doing. The responses were overwhelming

image.altText: Michael Jackson and other musicians look over sheet music together in a music studio.

props.synopsis: The compelling story behind iconic fundraiser song We Are The World makes for a suspenseful, star-studded pop music documentary.

title.children: How pop's biggest names pulled a secret marathon all-nighter to create history's biggest charity single

image.altText: young couple put sold sticker on billboard of their newly purchased home.

props.synopsis: House prices are on track to rise across the country, propelled by renters and migrants wanting to buy their own homes and buyers trying to get in ahead of interest rate cuts expected later this year.

title.children: The gap between house and unit prices has reached a record high, as values keep climbing

image.altText: Voluntary assisted dying recipient Lynne Wong.

props.synopsis: A year after voluntary assisted dying came into effect in South Australia, families of some of the 110 people who have opted to take that path describe their experiences.

title.children: Since SA introduced voluntary assisted dying laws, more than 100 people have opted for 'a death of their choosing'

image.altText: A penguin standing on the sand with its mouth open.

props.synopsis: As rising sea levels lead to more fish in the ocean around Phillip Island, off Australia's southern coast, polyamorous little penguins are using the extra energy to breed.

title.children: 'Sexually promiscuous' penguins are mating twice in one season as the climate changes

image.altText: Mary-Anne Thomas posing with a group of board members at Colac Area Health.

props.synopsis: Victoria's Department of Health investigates allegations "fake patients" were organised to appear at Colac Area Health's urgent care centre during a visit by the Health Minister last year.

title.children: Government investigates claim regional hospital staff and family posed as patients during minister's visit

image.altText: Margot Robbie wearing a pale pink sequined strapless mini dress with coreset-like detailing and sheer heels

props.synopsis: Margot Robbie has addressed controversy over Barbie's absence from the best director and best actress categories at the 2024 Oscars.

title.children: Margot Robbie breaks silence on Barbie Oscars snub

image.altText: Photo collage of Truman Capote and Marilyn Monroe.

props.synopsis: The Breakfast at Tiffany's author jetsetted with the likes of Gloria Vanderbilt and Jackie Kennedy's sister Lee Radziwill. But his choice to write about their best-kept secrets would ruin it all, as a new star-studded miniseries reveals.

title.children: Breakfast at Tiffany's exposed the underbelly of the upper class. Its author would die trying

image.altText: Jack Ziebell kicking a football

props.synopsis: The former North Melbourne star was hospitalised and required surgery after being attacked outside a pub in Melbourne's south last year.

title.children: Man who attacked AFL player Jack Ziebell hours after his final match avoids jail time

image.altText: Israeli drone in Gaza

props.synopsis: Approvals to export Australian made military equipment to Israel are being "stalled" by the Albanese government as concerns grow over the rising number of civilian casualties in Gaza.

title.children: Australia 'stalls' military export requests from Israel over Gaza war concerns, growing number of civilian casualties

image.altText: Lionel Messi looks to one side

props.synopsis: The napkin Lionel Messi signed to join Barcelona as a 13-year-old is up for auction in March, but that's nothing compared to some of the other odd pieces of sports memorabilia that have gone under the hammer.

title.children: Lionel Messi's napkin is up for auction and that's not even close to being the oddest piece of sports memorabilia for sale

image.altText: A man leaning against a wall of wooden alcohol barrels.

props.synopsis: More than half the cost of a bottle of spirits goes to the tax office. Distillers want a two-year pause on the "outrageous" excise, but the Alcohol and Drug Foundation says it's necessary to stop harmful drinking.

title.children: Distillers push for pause as spirit excise increases make favourite tipple more expensive
